cab.content: [This Document is the Property of His Britannic Majestys Government.]Printed for the War Cabinet. October 1918.SECRET.NAVAL WEEKLY APPRECIATION-No. 75.Week ended Wh October, 1918.NAVAL OPERATIONS.Minelaying in the North Sea has been continued.North Sea.Very little flying has taken place during the week owing to bad weather conditions. HanderaR.A.E. machines from Dunkirk, working with the Navy, have carried out several Area,reconnaissances over the Ghent area and also two raids on the railways in the vicinity ofLokeren and Termonde, about two tons of bombs being dropped. Several indecisivecombats took place. All our machines returned safely.On 20th October the Monitor M.21 struck a mine off Ostend and had to be beached. Casualty.Five men were killed.ATTACK UPON ENEMY SUBMARINES.jffiThe present situation is somewhat obscure and it is not possible to estimate the number Submarinesof enemy submarines which are operating. Except at the beginning of the week in the operating.Irish Sea, no activity has been experienced and at present the enemy appears to beconcentrating in the North Sea, but in what numbers it is impossible to say. There arehree converted Deutschlands at sea, one in the vicinity of the Azores and the other twoare believed to be somewhere in the Western Atlantic.The following Table shows the number of actions between Allied craft and enemy Actionssubmarines which are reported to have taken place in all waters during recent weeks entemyand the nature of the craft which have been engaged ; and also the number of submarines submarmes*which have been destroyed or lost to the enemy as the result of such actions : Week ended Week ended Week ended Week ended Oct. 5th. Oct. 12th. Oct. 19th. Oct. 26th. Nature of Craft, &c. Actions. Results. Actions. Results. Actions. Results. Actions. Results.Armed Merchant Cruiser J T.B.D. and T.B.......... 2 _ 2 _ 3 3 _A.P. Submarines possibly sunk are not included.(C 1491) Wt, - 50 11/18 H & S A MERCANTILE LOSSES BY ENEMY ACTION.Numberandtonnage ofall vesselssunk.The following is a Comparative Statement of the Number and Tonnage of all MerchantVessels sunk in recent weeks by enemy action : Week Ended British Vessels. September 14th 4 29,466 5 2,693 2 7.849 3 1,994 14 42,002September 21st 11 37,853 9* 6,231* 5 14,277 10 2,264 35* 60,625*September 28th 6 17,864 1 95 1 659 8 18,618October 5th 8 30,844 5* 3,509* 8 28,838 10 5,146 31* 68,337*October 12th 1 2,646 2 1,432 5* 16,618* 4 2,866* 12* 23,562*October 19th 5 18,257 2 879 2 212 9 19,348October 26th 2 473 2 473Areas inwhichreesels lost.* Adjusted.The Table in the Appendix is a comparative statement of all merchant vessels, Foreignas well as British, sunk, damaged and unsuccessfully attacked in the last two weeks byenemy craft and by mine, classified according to areas.During the week under review eight attacks were made on merchant vessels, but onlytwo, both in the Irish Sea, resulted in the loss of the vessel attacked. The vessels weresmall, the total tonnage amounting to only 473 gross tons.No attacks of any kind on merchant ships are reported after 23rd October, when oneship of 4,000 tons was attacked and damaged in the Mediterranean. The latest date onwhich an attack was made in Home Waters was the 22nd, when two attacks were' madein the Irish Sea.Vessels The number of British and Foreign merchant vessels sailing in organised Convoyconvoyed, ^yhich completed their voyages during last week, and the losses sustained whilst in suclConvoys, compared with corresponding figures for previous periods, are as follows :- Week ended Week ended. Week ended. Week ended 5th Oct., 1918. 12th Oct., 1918. 19th Oct., 1918. 26th Oct., 1918. Convoy. No. of No. of No. of No, of ships No. ships No. ships No. ships No. convoyed. lost. convoyed. lost. convoyed. -1- lost. convoyed. lost,Atlantic trades-Homeward .....Outward........Scandinavia-MethilFrench coal trade.....Local East Coast Convoys(N. of Humber)Mediterranean localTotal........1921151063574242031,39731153110663473822131,2711311541183515132061,47316894613564202271,326The loss of the two vessels, during the week ended 26th October, was caused bcollision.Quarterlylosses ofmerchanttonnage byenemyaction.During the quarter ended September last, 724,000 gross tons of merchant shippinwere sunk by enemy action.This is the lowest quarterly figure since the commencement of unrestricted submarinwarfare and is 12 per cent, less than the figure for the preceding quarter and 66 per centless than the corresponding figure for the quarter ended June, 1917, when the lossesmerchant shipping were at their maximum. 8ENEMY MINES.The suspected minefield oi! the East Coast of Scotland, referred to in last week's Minelaying.Appreciation, has been located, and 24 out of a probable 36 mines have already beenswept up.Minesweeping off Ostend has progressed satisfactorily and a channel between thatplace and Dunkirk has been cleared, together with Ostend harbour itself, and an areaextending for some distance towards Zeebrugge. A number of mines are known to existoff the last-mentioned place and the situation has been taken in hand in conjunction withthe French.In view of possible developments a concentration of fast minesweepers has been madeon the East Coast of Scotland.The following Table shows the number of enemy mines destroyed in British mine- Casualties,sweeping areas and of British vessels sunk by mine in recent weeks : Number of Enemy - Moored Mines Week Ended. Destroyed. Number of British Mine-sweepers and Patrols Number of British Merchant Steamships Sunk by Mines. Sunk by Mines. Home Waters. Abroad. Nil 2 Nil Nil12th ...... 2 10 Nil Nil19th ...... 3 1 Nil Nil26th 24 Nil 1 1In addition to the mines above mentioned, a total of 46, including those which struckships, have so far been accounted for off Ostend.The Motor Launch 521 was sunk, and H.M. Monitor M.21 was damaged, by mineduring the week off Ostend, and a British merchant ship was sunk off the coast of Sicily.ALLIED, NEUTRAL AND ENEMY MERCANTILE TONNAGE.The total Allied and Neutral merchant tonnage sunk by enemy action up to the end Allied andof September last amounted to over 12,600,000 gross tons, of which more than 11,000,000 Neutraltons were sunk by enemy submarine. In addition 211,000 tons of Allied shipping are in ^^^Vyenemy ports. by enemy.The total Enemy tonnage now under Allied or Neutral control, or which has been sunk tonnageduring the war, is approximately as follows : now under German. A number of mines are known to existoff the last-mentioned place and the situation has been taken in hand in conjunction withthe French.In view of possible developments a concentration of fast minesweepers has been madeon the East Coast of Scotland.The following Table shows the number of enemy mines destroyed in British mine- Casualties,sweeping areas and of British vessels sunk by mine in recent weeks : Number of Enemy - Moored Mines Week Ended. Monitor M.21 was damaged, by mineduring the week off Ostend, and a British merchant ship was sunk off the coast of Sicily.ALLIED, NEUTRAL AND ENEMY MERCANTILE TONNAGE.The total Allied and Neutral merchant tonnage sunk by enemy action up to the end Allied andof September last amounted to over 12,600,000 gross tons, of which more than 11,000,000 Neutraltons were sunk by enemy submarine. Austrian. Total.Position 1914 ..............,. New Construction ............... Less tonnage not now under enemy control Now in enemy's possession ...... Gross Tons. 5,425,000 375,000 Gross Tons. 1,000,000 59,000 Gross Tons. 6,425,000 434,000 5,800,000 3,605,000 1,059,000 493,000 6,859,000 4,098,000 2,195,000 566,000 2,761,000MOVEMENTS OF ENEMY SHIPS.During the week under review five enemy merchant ships arrived at and eightsailed from Norwegian ports outside the Cattegat. In addition, one enemy ship arrivedat Rotterdam, one arrived at Flushing from Antwerp, and one arrived at Terneuzen fromGhent.FOREIGN NAVAL INTELLIGENCE.Russia.On 23rd October the enemy attacked our positions on the River Dwina, but wererepulsed and a successful counter-attack was made. A prisoner reported that enemysteamers and barges are now being withdrawn to winter quarters at Seltzo.A train containing a British half-battalion has been derailed about 40 miles north ofKandalaksha. It was thought, at firtet, to have been an attempt at sabotage by Bolshevikagents, but it was later discovered to have been due to faulty rolling stock. GeneralMaynard is organizing a Karelian force to guard the railway, which has lately beenthreatened in several places by enemy agents.The ships of the Russian Black Sea Fleet, which are now reported to be manned byGerman personnel, are one Dreadnought and two pre-Dreadnought Battleships, twoCruisers, five oil burning and six other Destroyers and six Submarines.The Germans are withdrawing from the Caucasus.In consequence of the defection of their Trans-Caspian Allies, British troops on 21stOctober suffered a reverse at Dirshalda on the Central Asian Railway west of Merv. TheBolsheviks, however, suffered heavily and later withdrew east to Tejend, leaving muchmaterial and ammunition in our hands. Our cavalry has followed up the enemy to apoint 13 miles east of Dirshalda, and the Trans-Caspian troops are beginning to re-form,Three armed merchant ships in the Caspian are now ready and at sea, and two othersare expected to be ready within the next week. The Turks are reported to be armingtwo of the eight steamers now at Baku.A few German Naval Officers are stated to be at Baku, but there is no confirmation ofthe report that a submarine in parts had arrived there.Discipline in the two Russian Gunboats forming the Caspian Fleet is said to have much Iimproved. These ships are now under the orders of Bicharakov, who is reported to bepfriendly but suspicious of our action in the Caspian. He is short of ammunition.Naval Staff,Zlst October, 1918,[Appendix, Statement of the number of British and Foreign Merchant Vessels sunk, damaged or molestedduring weeks ended 19th and 26th October, 1918, according to Areas.
